Author: palish
Title: Would Arc benefit from [] replacing ()?
Content: On standard qwerty keyboards, typing [], which can be typed with just your pinkie, seems far easier than typing (), which requires at least two fingers and movement of your right hand.  What do you all think?

Author: edgeztv
Content:
I think this is the way to go. I am taking this approach for a multi-player game I'm developing - you can play without registering, but you can register afterwards to save your score.

My primary project, mystorespace.com, takes a similar approach. We have a fully functional demo accessible without an account (you will be automatically logged in as testuser@mystorespace.com). I really don't like having to register in order to try something, so I assume most users feel the same way.

Author: henning
Content:
It kinda just takes time.

I think the ideal situation would be having something like Job B for a while until you feel like you're a solidly professional duder, and then move on to something more risky and adventurous. I wasted vast amounts of time trying to teach myself to program as a teenager because I didn't know where to go to. Having some structure and guidance could help you.

Author: amichail
Title: How do you make "arrogant" blogs acceptable?  Build a service dedicated to them?
Content:
By arrogant, I mean something like a blog where you talk about your own ideas. Examples:

http://bramcohen.livejournal.com/

http://ideas.4brad.com/

http://mindrosity.blogspot.com/

IMO, there is nothing inherently wrong with these blogs. The problem is that people have certain expectations of what a blog is and these sorts of blogs do not meet those expectations.

Author: luxiou
Content: I would take the first job. It will likely put you in more "if I don't figure this out, nobody else will, and we'll be completely screwed" type situations, and those can be great motivators for doing/learning things you never would have bothered with otherwise.
